reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central assumption class: that (partial) moral reflection/aiming-at-the-good can meaningfully steer outcomes in a post-AGI world. If true, it would undercut both WAM-convergence hopes and some of the trade/compromise optimism by suggesting power-maximizing selection dominates. However, the position explicitly discusses closely related “blockers,” including trajectories driven by evolutionary forces rather than deliberation (2.5) and self-interested dynamics (4.1), so the critique is partly ‘priced in’ rather than a novel refutation of the core thesis. The critique’s argumentative force is limited: it mostly asserts strong Darwinian-outcompetition dynamics without engaging the essay’s mechanisms (delegated reflection via AI, bargaining institutions, power distribution, lock-in timing) or offering evidence that reflection/‘de dicto’ motivation is systematically maladaptive rather than potentially instrumentally advantageous. Many claims are plausible but overstated/uncertain (e.g., that reflection necessarily implies competitive delay; that post-AGI selection is dominated by replication/belligerence rather than coordination/contracting). It is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Darwinian selection pressures favor power-maximizers over morally reflective agents
